awd_titl_txt: Interdisciplinary Study of Chemical and Transport Processes at a Plasma-Liquid Interface
awd_abstract_narration:
This project focuses on improving the understanding of the fundamental processes that occur at or near interfaces of a plasma, a cloud of ionized gas composed of electrons, ions and neutral particles, and a liquid. A plasma that is created above or within a liquid can have a number of uses.  For example, plasma discharges have been used to sterilize water, fruit juices, and milk, to remove harmful chemicals from water, to create new materials, and for medical applications. Some cancer-causing pollutants found in the environment can only be treated using plasmas. In material processing technologies plasmas formed directly in liquids that do not contain water, such as alcohols, can transform these liquids into different useful products including carbon nanotubes, a material with unique properties that is currently used in a wide variety of electronics. A better understanding of the physical and chemical processes near the plasma-liquid interface will not only help to improve the existing plasma-based processes, but will also open new applications in biomedicine, agriculture, energy, green chemistry and pollutant mitigation. 
 
The region near the plasma-liquid interface exhibits complex dynamics that depend on the formation of reactive radicals, ions and high energy electrons, their transport across the interface, and the physics of the bulk fluid motion for mixing and transport. These processes are interrelated and incorporate both physical and chemical dynamics. The overall goal of this research project is to determine relationships between the physical and chemical processes occurring at the plasma-liquid interface in a system where the plasma discharge contacts the liquid surface. Two specific goals of this study are to: (1) Correlate the bulk liquid transport processes with the plasma-liquid interface dynamics and (2) Determine the significance of the plasma excited species transport in the kinetics of interfacial processes. The approach for achieving the goals of this multidisciplinary study is to identify degradation mechanisms of several compounds of interest and apply quantitative optical diagnostic tools (i.e. Particle Image Velocimetry and Laser-Induced Fluorescence) to understand the physics at the interface as well as the role bulk liquid transport plays in the dynamics of the degradation process. Further, molecular dynamics simulations will be performed to develop a quantitative understanding of the microstructure of the studied compounds at the gas-liquid interface.

por.por_cntn:
Plasmas formed directly in and contacting a liquid have been used to sterilize water, synthesize materials and nanoparticles, and for applications in plasma medicine and polymer surface treatment. However, the optimization and broader application of electrical discharge plasmas in and contacting a liquid have been limited due to a general lack of understanding of the underlying physical and chemical processes occurring at the plasma-liquid interface. This region exhibits complex and convoluted dynamics that depends on the formation of reactive radicals, ions and high energy electrons, their transport across the interface, and the physics of the bulk fluid motion for mixing and transport. This research project focused on determining the relationships between the physical and chemical processes occurring at the plasma-liquid interface in a system where plasma contacts the surface of liquid water.

We have developed a mechanistic model that accurately predicts the degradation rates of different types of organic compounds in terms of individual contributions to degradation from each of three general mechanisms thought to occur at or near the gas-liquid interface: sub-surface, surface and above-surface. According to this model, sub-surface reactions occur just underneath the gas-liquid interface between the contaminants and dissolved plasma-generated radicals, contributing significantly to the removal of compounds that lack surfactant-like properties and so are not highly concentrated at the interface. Surface reactions occur at the interface between the contaminants and dissolved radicals, contributing significantly to the removal of surfactant-like compounds that have high interfacial concentrations. Above-surface reactions are proposed to take place in the plasma interior between highly energetic plasma species and exposed portions of compounds that extend out of the interface. This work has shown that not all the compounds are degraded at equal rates and that only the compounds that exhibit surfactant-like behavior and are thus more concentrated at the interface, can be successfully used to study interfacial kinetics.

In the absence of external mixing, the convective mass transfer in the bulk liquid plays a critical role in the plasma reactor performance (i.e., compound degradation rate) but only if the concentration of the compound (i.e., solute) in the solution is below a certain threshold. For our system, two qualitatively different regimes were identified depending on the instantaneous compound concentration: a chemical reaction limited regime for high solute concentrations and a mass transport limited regime for low solute concentrations. For the former regime we have demonstrated that the compound degradation rate is determined by the rate of reactive species production (i.e., species flux), which is directly proportional to the number of discharge pulses, that is, the discharge frequency. For the transport limited regime, liquid surface velocity data obtained from particle image velocimetry measurements revealed that compounds' degradation rate constants are proportional to the surface speeds that arise from Marangoni stresses. The latter are formed from the spatial gradients in compounds' interfacial concentrations that are created in the x-direction between the low concentration (destructive) region at the interface contacting the plasma and the high concentration (non-destructive) region at the interface outside the plasma formation zone.

Bulk liquid organic composition has rarely if ever been thought of influencing interfacial chemistry. However, this work has clearly shown that changes in the operational parameters and bulk liquid solution composition strongly affect not only the convective mass transport, that is, liquid surface velocities, but also the fluxes of plasma-generated reactive species. The results of this study are widely applicable to any gas discharge plasma reactor to fine tune its performance and enable its further development to a commercial product. In fact, the fundamental findings resulting from this study enabled the development and commercialization of the enhanced contact reactor, a plasma-based technology for the treatment of contaminated water containing poly- and perfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS), also known as forever chemicals. To date, no other destructive technology has been able to degrade these contaminants competitively. This project directly supported 1 PhD student and 1 MS student and has provided numerous opportunities for training of undergraduate students. The principal investigators have been actively involved in educating the local children in science and technology via the North Country Children's Museum where they organized workshops and assisted with permanent engineering exhibits.
